DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of fixative used to preserve a biospecimen.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A findings domain that documents biospecimen handling information._Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._A compound that preserves tissues and cells for microscopic study.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A findings domain that documents biospecimen handling information.

Concepts.definition: A findings domain that documents biospecimen handling information.

Property.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.:A compound that preserves tissues and cells for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.
A compound that preserves tissues and cells for microscopic study.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Released. AK 2020-6-10; Created for CDSIC aligned NCI Standard CRFs. ghd

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the field to identify the type of fixative used to preserve a tissue specimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The information was not captured or stored.

Concepts.definition: The information was not captured or stored.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary system comprised of a formalin-free tissue fixative and stabilizing reagent designed to preserve tissue structures without damaging biomolecules. This allows both histologic examination and isolation of RNA, miRNA, DNA, and/or proteins from a single sample.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary system comprised of a formalin-free tissue fixative and stabilizing reagent designed to preserve tissue structures without damaging biomolecules. This allows both histologic examination and isolation of RNA, miRNA, DNA, and/or proteins from a single sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No Value Exists

Concepts.definition: No Value Exists

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of reagents that reacts with the epsilon-amino group of lysine and forms intermolecular cross-links within proteins. These agents may be used as tissue fixatives for electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry.

Concepts.definition: A group of reagents that reacts with the epsilon-amino group of lysine and forms intermolecular cross-links within proteins. These agents may be used as tissue fixatives for electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.8.15 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002731. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.

Concepts.definition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A water-soluble oily liquid, C5H8O2, containing two aldehyde groups, used as a disinfectant and as a fixative for biological tissues.

Concepts.definition: A water-soluble oily liquid, C5H8O2, containing two aldehyde groups, used as a disinfectant and as a fixative for biological tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solution of salt and water. Saline usually refers to normal or physiological saline, which is an aqueous solution containing 0.9% sodium chloride.

Concepts.definition: A solution of salt and water. Saline usually refers to normal or physiological saline, which is an aqueous solution containing 0.9% sodium chloride.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: OCT media
Trade name for an aqueous, non-toxic tissue storage reagent that rapidly permeates tissues to stabilize and protect cellular RNA.

Concepts.definition: Trade name for an aqueous, non-toxic tissue storage reagent that rapidly permeates tissues to stabilize and protect cellular RNA.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: A specimen has no preservative and is processed as fresh tissue

ValueMeaning.preferredName: A specimen has no preservative and is processed as fresh tissue
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: a specimen has no preservative and is processed as fresh tissue

A volatile liquid prepared by fermentation of certain carbohydrates. Alcohol acts as a central nervous system (CNS) depressant, a diuretic, and a disinfectant. Although the exact mechanism of CNS depression is unknown, alcohol may act by inhibiting the opening of calcium channels, mediated by the binding of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-amino butyric acid (GABA) to GABA-A receptors, or through inhibitory actions at N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors. Alcohol inhibits the production of antidiuretic hormone, thereby producing diuresis that may lead to dehydration. This agent kills organisms by denaturing their proteins.

Concepts.definition: A volatile liquid prepared by fermentation of certain carbohydrates. Alcohol acts as a central nervous system (CNS) depressant, a diuretic, and a disinfectant. Although the exact mechanism of CNS depression is unknown, alcohol may act by inhibiting the opening of calcium channels, mediated by the binding of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-amino butyric acid (GABA) to GABA-A receptors, or through inhibitory actions at N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors. Alcohol inhibits the production of antidiuretic hormone, thereby producing diuresis that may lead to dehydration. This agent kills organisms by denaturing their proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless, volatile, flammable organic solvent.  Acetone occurs naturally in plants, trees, forest fires, vehicle exhaust and as a breakdown product of animal fat metabolism.  This agent may be normally present in very small quantities in urine and blood; larger amounts may be found in the urine and blood of diabetics.  Acetone is toxic in high doses. (NCI04)

Concepts.definition: A colorless, volatile, flammable organic solvent.  Acetone occurs naturally in plants, trees, forest fires, vehicle exhaust and as a breakdown product of animal fat metabolism.  This agent may be normally present in very small quantities in urine and blood; larger amounts may be found in the urine and blood of diabetics.  Acetone is toxic in high doses. (NCI04)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A serum- and protein-free cryopreservation medium for biological specimens that minimizes cellular damage following freezing and thawing.

Concepts.definition: A serum- and protein-free cryopreservation medium for biological specimens that minimizes cellular damage following freezing and thawing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-ionic triblock copolymer comprised of a hydrophobic core of polyoxypropylene flanked by two hydrophilic side chains of polyoxyethylene, that may be used as a fixative and as solubilizer, emulsifier and stabilizer in drug delivery systems.

Concepts.definition: A non-ionic triblock copolymer comprised of a hydrophobic core of polyoxypropylene flanked by two hydrophilic side chains of polyoxyethylene, that may be used as a fixative and as solubilizer, emulsifier and stabilizer in drug delivery systems.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A denaturing fixative consisting of ethanol, chloroform and glacial acetic acid in a 6:3:1 ratio. It is particularly effective for the preservation of nuclei and in retaining glycogen.

Concepts.definition: A denaturing fixative consisting of ethanol, chloroform and glacial acetic acid in a 6:3:1 ratio. It is particularly effective for the preservation of nuclei and in retaining glycogen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A liquid preservative for cytological materials, consisting of methanol and glacial acetic acid in an approximately 3:1 ratio. It is typically used on tissues to be paraffin-embedded and immunochemically stained and is useful for the preservation of nucleic acids in situ.

Concepts.definition: A liquid preservative for cytological materials, consisting of methanol, chloroform and glacial acetic acid in a 6:3:1 ratio. It is typically used on tissues to be paraffin-embedded and immunochemically stained and is useful for the preservation of nucleic acids in situ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A detergent-based cell lysis buffer suitable for total protein extraction. The formulation helps retain the protein structure and function for enzyme assays or immunoassays.

Concepts.definition: A detergent-based cell lysis buffer suitable for total protein extraction. The formulation helps retain the protein structure and function for enzyme assays or immunoassays.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary buffer containing RNase inhibitors designed for cell lysis and the extraction and collection of mRNA from cell samples.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary buffer containing RNase inhibitors designed for cell lysis and the extraction and collection of mRNA from cell samples.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A dipolar aprotic solvent and reagent that may be used in the production of fibers and pharmaceuticals, and as a non-aldehyde fixative.

Concepts.definition: A dipolar aprotic solvent and reagent that may be used in the production of fibers and pharmaceuticals, and as a non-aldehyde fixative.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A group of reagents that crosslinks amines and carboxylates, that may be used as a fixative and in peptide conjugation.

Concepts.definition: A group of reagents that crosslinks amines and carboxylates, that may be used as a fixative and in peptide conjugation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An aqueous dilution of ethanol containing 95% ethanol by volume, which may be used as a solvent, disinfectant or fixative.

Concepts.definition: An aqueous dilution of ethanol containing 95% ethanol by volume, which may be used as a solvent, disinfectant or fixative.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 1/12/22 mr Versioned to 4.0 to add 6 MCL PVs w permission of Brenda D.     4/13/21 jk added 6 HTAN PVs.  2/6/19 jk added Alcohol and Acetone PVs for MCL Specimen tracking system; 2/11/19 smt -ownership transfer from CTEP approved by Brian Campbell.

ReferenceDocuments.name: CDISC Aligned NCI Standard Equivalent CDE
ReferenceDocuments.description: This data element is to be used for CDISC aligned data collection in place of CDE 65078 from the original NCI Standard CRF Template.

DataElement.changeDescription: Released. AK 2020-6-17; Created for CDSIC aligned NCI Standard CRFs. ghd CDE versioned to change short name from BSSPFXTP to FIXNAM per TESTCD naming convention decision. mc 5.14.20; 20220301 versioned CDE to use newer VD version bsm.
